<plain_text><page sequence="1">Ninety-seventh Critical Bibliography of the History of Science and its Cultural Influences (to January 1972) The ninety-seventh Critical Bibliography,* which in- cludes 3240 citations, is the eighteenth to be classified according to the system established in 1953. The main purpose of the classification has always been, in the words of its founder, George Sarton, "to satisfy the needs of historians of science in general rather than those of historians of particular sciences". While the classification is both chronological and by subject, pre- ference is given to the former. The reader who wishes to find all references to a particular subject, therefore, must examine several sections of the bibliography. Contnrbuting Scholars This bibliography was compiled with the aid of a number of scholars, among whom the following have undertaken systematic examnination of particular jour- nals or subject areas, orhave contributed in other ways: Elizabeth Barton, American Institute of Physics Leon Bloom, SUNY, Oswego Carl Boyer, Brooklyn College Stephen Brush, University of Maryland Carolyn Eisele, Hunter College Ralph Ehrenberg, National Archives Ralph Ehrenberg, National Archives June Fullmer, Ohio State University Mel Gorman, University of San Francisco Edward Grant, Indiana University Roger Hahn, University of Califomia, Berkeley C. Doris Hellman, Queens College Sandra Herbert, University of Maryland David Joravsky, Northwestem University George B. Kauffman, Fresno State College Camille Limoges, University of Montreal Alexander M. Ospovat, Oklahoma State University M. Rechcigl, Jr., Agency for Intemational Develop- ment, Dept. of State Nathan Sivin, Massachusetts Institute of Technology William A. Smeaton, University College, London Jerry Stannard, University of Kansas Deborah J. Warner, Smithsonian Institution George W. White, University of Illinois This Critical Bibliography is endorsed by the History of Sci- ence Division of the International Union of the History and Philosophy of Science. Book Reviews Since the bibliography is now back on schedule, the time-consuming task of citing book reviews will be resumed. Book reviews will be found listed at the end of the classified section of the bibliography. No at- tempt was made to cite reviews which have appeared since the last book-review list, except for reviews in Isis, all of which have been cited. Jounal Abbreviations This bibliography contains citations from the following periodicals and serials, with abbreviations according to the World List of Scientific Periodicals or the Ameri- can National Standard for the Abbreviation of Titles of Periodicals. Those marked a are searched regularly each year by the staff of the CB aid are included in the list whether or not a reference has been made to them in the present CB. Scholars publishing articles pertinent to the scope of this bibliography in journals not marked * are urged to notify the editor so the article can be entered in the CB. Wissenschaftstheorie) *Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenlandischen Gesell- schaft (Z. Dt. MorgenlUnd. Ges.) *Zeitschrift fiir Philosophische Forschung (Z. Phil. Forsch.) *Zygon Other Bibliographies There are a number of other bibliographies of current work that the historian of science should consult in conjunction with this Critical Bibliography. The most important of these are: Bibliography of the History of Medicine. Bethesda, Md.: National Library of Medicine. Published annually. Bulletin Signaletique 522: Histoire des sciences et des techniques. Paris: Centre de documentation du C.N.R.S. Published quarterly. Current Bibliography in the History of Technology. Published annually in the journal Technology and Culture. Current Work in the History of Medicine. London: Weilcome Institute of the History of Medicine. Published quarterly. Acknowledgments The editor wishes to thank Rima Apple and Philip Teigen, graduate students in the History of Science at the University of Wisconsin, for their assistance in the compilation of the present bibliography. "I think ... that an important degree of interdependence [between science and technologyI is theoretically irremed- iable, is not to be lamented ... Science as metaphor: The historical role of scientific theories in forming Western culture. x + 321 pp., bibls. Belmont, Calif.: Wadsworth, 1971. $5.95 (paper). An anthology blending the writings of scientists (Newton, A.R. Wallace, Skinner, Margenau), writers (Hobbes, Henry Adams, Zola) and historians of science (Mason, Shapiro, Lenoble, Guerlac, Hiebert) on topics pertaining to the interaction of science and culture. 13 PELCZAR, MARLIN. The extensive holdings in the history of science of this great library are widely known. This catalog will be a great aid to historians., 21 BROCK, WILLIAM H. The first volume in a new series of indexes to older scientific and medical joursals not previously indexed. Contains 1177 entries reporting on the archives of business and industry (350), the collections of private individuals (282), and the repository holdings of colleges, observatories, smaller public libraries and historical societies that have not previously reported their holdings. There is a subject and name index. 29 MARTIN, CHARLES T. The record interpreter. A new joumal which contains articles of bibliographical interest (listed elsewhere in this CB) as well as a list of reprinted works, indexes of joumals, news of new publi- cations, congresses, theses, etc. While the joumal is nomin- ally devoted to French literature, much of the material is of interest to the historian of ideas. 32 SCIENTIFIC and technological manuscripts. HISTORIOGRAPHY AND HISTORICAL METHOD (general works on history, histories of the history of science, and such ancillary disciplines as paleography and chronology) AGASSI, JOSEPH. Can we learn from history? Actes XIIe Cong. Int. Hist. Sci., 1968 (pub. 1970), 2:5-8. "I contend that it will be much easier and much more challenging to science students to have in their texts false hypotheses and false rationales, and erroneous deductions stated and corrected. This historians of science can help to bring about." 39 BECKMAN, T. A. On the use of historical examples in Agassi's 'Sensationalism'. Stud. Hist. Phil Sci, 1970, 1:293-309. "I have no intention of addressing the principal themes brought up in J. Agassi's paper 'Sensationalism' [Mind, 1966, 75:1 1ff]. I am interested, instead, in the increasingly wide- spread practice of using historical examples to serve philo- sophical purposes, and I propose to use Agassi's paper as a case study. My intention is to examine the relationship between history and philosophy and to emphasize the need for reasonable standards of historical scholarship in those cases where historical examples are proposed as instances of philo- sophical generalizations." Agassi's response appears Stud Hist. Phil. Sci, 1971,2:157-165. 40 BELLONI, LuIGI. La repetition des experiences anciennes et son utilite pour l'histoire des sciences. Actes XIIe Cong. Int. Hist. Sci., 1968 (pub. 1970), 2: 13-16. 41 BENNETT, JOHN F. An appeal for the history of scientific inspiration. Actes XIIe Cong. Int. Hist. Sci, 1968 (pub. 1970), 2:17-20. 42 CANTOR, NORMAN F. Perspectives on the Euro- pean past: Conversations with historians. xix + 359 + 362 pp. New York: Macmillan, 1971. $11.95. Includes a conversation with A. R. Hall on the Scientific Revolution (pp. 344-359) and Frank E. Manuel on the Enlightenment and the history of ideas (pp. 2740). 43 CLARK, JOSEPH T. The science of history and the history of science. Psychoanalysis and historical bio- graphy. J. Am. Psychoanal, Ass., 1971, 19:143-179. Considers the history of psychoanalytic approaches to biography, methodological problems in psychoanalytical biography, the biographical study of public figures, and the current status of psychoanalytic biography. 48 MC GILL, WILLIAM J. Herbert Butterfield and the idea of liberty. S. Atlan. Q., 1971, 70:1-12. On Butterfield's ideas on historiography. 49 PRICE, DEREK J. DE SOLLA. Who's who in the History of Science: A survey of our profession. Actes XIIe Cong. Int. Hist. Sci., 1968 (pub. 1970), 2:79-87. First published in Technology + Society, 1969, 5(2):52-55. 50 ROSEN, EDWARD. Was Copernicus a Hermetist? Pp. 163-171 in Roger H. Stuewer (ed.) Historical and philosophical perspectives of science. Minneapolis: Univ. Minnesota Pr., 1970. "The general thesis of this paper is that a satisfactory history of science must be intemal, but also must take account of external factors; it must combine comprehension of the scientific subject matter with a broad understanding of the historical period. This thesis is illustrated by discussing one of Archimedes' discoveries, and, especially, by analyzing the validity of Miss Yates's contention that Copernicus in his scientific work was strongly influenced by magical beliefs associated with the hermetic-cabalist tradition." From the summary. 51 SHORTER, EDWARD. The historian and the com- puter: A practical guide. x + 149 pp., index. Englewood Cliffs, N. J.: Prentice-Hall, 1971. $6.95. 52 SZABADVARY, FERENC. Reflections on the present and future of the history of science. J. Chem. Educ., 1971,48:282-284. The 1970 Dexter Award Address in the History of Chemistry. Science and technology are the determinant factors influenc- ing the future, and the future development of science and technology cannot be judged or predicted without consider- ation of their history. A brief history of Hungarian chemistry is given from early metallurgical advances in the Middle Ages through the emigration of scientists to more prosperous countries (the "brain drain"). The contributions of a number of Hungarian chemists are briefly discussed. G. B. KAUFFMAN 53 HS 4. SCIENCE AND ITS HISTORY FROM SPECIAL POINTS OF VIEW (works involving two or more subjects or chronological periods) HS 10. PHILOSOPHY OF SCIENCE AND METHODS OF SCIENCE (general works only; those devoted to a special period or persons are found below under D) ACHINSTEIN, PETER. Law and explanation: An essay in the philosophy of science. xii + 168 pp., illus., index. London: Oxford Univ. Pr., 1971. ?2.75. 57 AGASSI, JOSEPH. Duhem's instrumentalism and autonomism. Ratio, 1970,12:148-150. 58 AGASSI, JOSEPH. What is a natural law? Studium Generale, 1971,24:1051-1056. 59 BHATTACHARYA, BIRENDRA K. Causality in science and philosophy: A historical and critical survey. 201 pp., bibl. Calcutta: Sanskrit Pustak Bhandar, 1969. Rs 18.00. 60 BLACHOWICZ, JAMES A. Systems theory and evolutionary models of the development of science. Philosophy Sci, 1971, 38:178-199. "Philosophers of science [e.g. Kuhn and Popper] have used various formulations of the 'random mutation-natural selection' scheme to explain the development of scientific knowledge. But the uncritical acceptance of this evolutionary model has led to substantive problems concerning the relation between fact and theory . . . Systems theory consti- tutes a general criticism of this model insofar as it demon- strates the necessity of supplementing this mechanism with the non-random influences exercised by the internal organiz- ation of a system on its own development." From the summary. 61 BLACKBURN, THOMAS R. Sensuous-intellectual complementarity in science. Science, 1971, 1 72: 1003-1007. "It is conceivable, then, that the notion of complementarity offers a method of including both sensuous and intellectual knowledge of nature in a common frame of reference. The result, far more than a mere compromise or amalgarnation of the two viewpoints, could be a richer science, in which esthetic and quantitative valuations, each retaining its own integrity, would contribute equally to the description of nature that science long ago took for its province. Further, it may produce a scientific ethic that is less destructive toward nature." 62 BLOOR, DAVID. Two paradigms for scientific knowledge? Sci. Stud. (London), 1971, 1:101-115. Essay review of I. Lakatos and A. Musgrave (eds.) Criticism and the growth of knowledge (Cambridge, 1970). 63 BUCHDAHL, GERD. History and methodology. Hist. Sci., 1970, 9:93-101. An essay review of W. M. O'Neil, Fact and theory: An aspect of philosophy of science (Sidney, 1969). 64 BUNGE, MARIO. Is scientific metaphysics possible? J. Phil., 1971, 68:507-520. "We have exhibited three theories ... that satisfy the con- ditions defuning scientific metaphysics. We have thereby proved that scientific metaphysics is not only possible but actual. It is particularly alive in engineering schools, although it is doubtful that engineers will be flattered by this association." 65 COLODNY, ROBERT G. (ed.) Pittsburgh: Univ. Pittsburgh Pr., 1970. $12.95. Contents: Grover Maxwell: Theories, perception, and structural realism. Mary Hesse: Is there an independent observation language? Abner Shimony: Scientific inference. Wesley C Salmon: Statistical explanation. Norwood Russell Hanson: A picture theory of theory meaning. Paul K. Feyerabend: Problems of empiricism, part 2. 66 DELEUZE, GILLES. Un nouvel archiviste. Critique, 1970:195-209. Ernst Cassirer: Scientific knowledge and the concept of man. xi + 286 pp., port., bibl., index. Notre Dame: Univ. Notre Dame Pr., 1971. $9.95. "The purpose of this study ... is twofold. The first is principally a matter of exegesis, to delineate from Cassirer's own writings the historical and systematic sources for his intellectual position. The second is to examine the implica- tions of this critico-idealistic philosophy for a theory of man and discursive knowledge, two prevasive themes in Cassirer's neo-Kantianism." Contents: The historic issue from Galileo to Hume. The critical Kant. Newtonianism and the status of scientific knowledge. Relativity and quantum theory. From science to culture: Language. Aphasia and common-sense thought. Man as symbolic animal. The direction of knowledge. 82 JOJA, CRIZANTEMA. Pour une histoire de la philosophie des sciences. Actes XIIe Cong. Int. Hist. Sci, 1968 (pub. 1970), 2:55-61. 83 KOCKELMANS, JOSEPH J.; THEODORE J. KISIEL (eds.) Phenomenology and the natural sciences: Essays and translations. (Northwestern University studies in phenomenology &amp; existential philosophy.) xxi + 520 pp., bibl., index. Evanston: Northwestern Univ. Pr., 1970. $15. 84 KOECHER, KAREL F. Ideology, philosophy and science. Diss. Abs. Int., 1971, 32:488-A. Dissertation at Columbia Univ., 1970. Univ. Microfilms order no. 71-17514. 186 pp. $4 film; $10 xerox. "The objective of the work is a systematic and comparative analysis of philosophy, science and ideology. It is contended that the three types of thought can be characterized and dis- tinguished according to the cognitive claims they make; and that the cognitive claims, in their tum, are characterized by the different criteria of truth invoked in the substantiation of philosophic, scientific and ideological assertionso." 85 KONFEDERATOV, IVAN I. From the abstract. 108 TOULMIN, STEPHEN. Reasons and causes. Pp. 1-48 in Robert Borger and Frank Cioffi (eds.) Explanation in the behavioural sciences. Cambridge: Cambridge Univ. Pr., 1970. 109</page><page sequence="15">20 10. Plhilosophy of Science 12. Scientific Instruments WHITROW, GERAID J. An analysis of the evolution of scientific method. Age Science (Paris), 1970, 3:255.280. "The nature of Scientific Method is a curiously elusive prob- lem. I believe that we cannot come to grips with it if we confne our attention to current science. Instead, we must try to understand how science has evolved and the way in which fundamental methodological advances have actually occurred. It is the object of the present paper to present an evolutionary conception of scientific method involving four distinct stages of development." 110 WISDOM, J. 0. Four contemporary interpretations of the nature of science. Found Physics, 1971 1:269-384. "Instmmentalism is an approach to science that treats a theory as a tool and only as a tool for computation; it dis- penses with the concept ef truth. Coventionaslim treats a theory as true by convention if it forms a pattern of observ- ations from which correct predictions can be made. Opera- tionalism denies meaning to the concepts of a theory unless they can be defined operationally. It is argued in this paper that truth-value is indispensable to science because a theory can be rejected only if an empirical consequence is false and if falsity of a conclusion entails falsity of a premise. This under- mines the above positions. The fourth interpretation is induc- tion. Induction, by contrast, uses the niotion of truth-value. What is focused on here is its reliance on the ultimacy of observation. The present thesis is that instrumentalism, con- ventionalism, and induction are different attempts to handle observations. The common problem is the gap between data and theory. All these interprtations share a philosophy of observationaliam. The aim of this paper is to show that the several orthodox interpretations of science all fail to solve the problem of the date-theory gap, and to show that they all presuppose a philosophy of observation." From the summary. 111 WUSSING, HANS L. Zur Entwicklungsgeschichte naturwissenschaftlicher Begriffe. Gewidmet dem 100. Geburtstag von W. I. Lenin. NTM, 1970, 7(2):15-29. 112 HS 11. Englewood Cliffs: Prentice-Hall, 1971. $6.95. "The topics dealt with are as follows: 1) the social role of the people who created and transmitted scientific knowledge in the traditional societies of antiquity and the Middle Ages; 2) the problem of why the study of empiical natural science had never, during these periods, become a distinct intellectual role, equal in infuence and dignity to the roles of moralists, metaphysicians, lawyers, and specialists in religious learning; 3) the conditions which led to the separation of the role of the scientist from other intellectual roles in 17th-century Europe, and to the professionalization of science in the 19th and 20th centuries; 4) the principal stages in the development of the organizations of scientific work, such as scientific academies of the 17th and 18th centuries, the scientific university of the 19th and 20th centuries, and the research institutes and industrial research laboratories startine the last decades of the 19th century. The subject is treated from a historical and comparative perspective." From the introduction. 136 BERLINGUER, GIOVANNI. Politica della scienza. (I1 Punto, 51.) 254 pp. Rome: Editori-Riuniti, 1970. "The scientist knows that at some point ... a research, if it is ever to have relevance to science, must become eligible for status as a scientific finding, and a scientific finding, in turn, becomes genuine only if it can contribute to the understanding of a previously unexplained phenomenon. The long judicious procedure by which this conversion is made is unique to science. To organize it for the sake of speed, or for open communication with other spheres of intellectual endeavour, would almost certainly dismnantie the institution of science as we know it today." 172 GASTON, JERRY C. Social science research policies in the United States. Minerva, 1971, 9:7-31. "The indirect consequences of social science research can be more important than its intellectual purpose, and that govem- ment research programme will be most successful which has the keenest appreciation of this fact. A new research pro- gramme can put life into a moribund university or govem- ment agency; a good programme can alert, and a poor pro- gramme blind, a govermment to popular discontent; research can be an instrument of public enlightenment or oppression. It is the task of politics to determine how knowledge is used. As war is too important to be left to generals, so knowledge is too important to be left to scholars.' 220 PAIGE, L. J. The author considers three successive stages in the evolutionary process of scientific society in England and America: the stages of elegant asiateurs, of poor professionals, and of dominant dukes. He concludes that some new social accom- m1odation and organization of the scientific enterprise is now in process of formation as evidenced from the present restless- ness in the larger scientific and political community. From a historians perspective the central question is whether specialist societies will reorganize m ways that help accom- modate broader social concems or whether such societies will undergo a relative decline in importance. "The system of monitoring scientific work before it enters into the archives of science means that much of the time scientists can build upon the work of others with a degree of warranted confidence. "After a preliminary discussion of the logical and general conceptual structure of commonsense, I shall examine the apparent opposition between commonsense and scientific theories and similar oppositions between different scientific theories. I shall next examine the apparent opposition between commonsense and abstract codes of conduct and similar oppositions between different codes of conduct. Lastly I shall consider a seemingly fundamental conflict between factual, especially scientific, thinking on the one hand and moral thinking on the other." 308 LASZLO, ERVIN. Notes on the poverty of con- temporary philosophy. Zygon, 1971, 6:48-54. Philosophers "examine the perennial questions of philosophy as though no empirical sciences existed-or at least as if their inquiry were prior to the theories of such sciences. Questions concerning knowledge, mind, obligation, value, etc., are pur- sued by these philosophers on the assumption that whatever evidence is available to a consistent and critical thinker in his daily life is sufficient to decide ... the issues." 309 LASZLO, ERVIN; JAMES B. Abstract: There is a relatively simple argument which shows that science is not, in any important sense, value free. Further, if science is not value free, it may be that the values involved in science rest upon moral considerations. In this paper the author examines one argument for the claim that science essentially involves value, and then looks at the types of values which may be an essential facet of scientific inquiry. 313 MEYER-BAER, KATHI. "Metalogic, an area of contemporary mathematical logic, reveals that the continuing failure to solve some of the unsolved arithmetic problems may be due not to lack of ingenuity but rather to inherent limitations of the capacities of both men and machines. This possibility gives metalogic philosophical as well as mathematical interest. It was through a refinement of some original Greek aims that mathematical logic came into being in the late 19th and early 20th century. Hence our account begis with Aristotle, who invented logic." Discusses mainly Aristotle, Zeno of Elea, Euclid, N. I. Lobachevsky and Karl Friedrich Gauss, Georg Cantor, Kurt Godel and Alonzo Church. 355</page><page sequence="29">34 21. "My purpose .. . is. . . to produce what perhaps might be descnbed as a chapter of 'applied history of science' in an attempt to show how the history of dynamics can be used to illuminate our understanding of the foundations of the subject." 450 WIGNER, EUGENE P. Physics and the explanation of life. Found Physics, 1970, 1:3545. "It is proposed to consider present-day physics as desling with a special situation, the situation in which the phenomena of life and consciousness play no role. It is pointed out that physical theory has often dealt, in the past, with similarly special situations. Planetary theory neglects all but gravita- tional forces, microscopic physics neglects fluctuations due to the atomic structure of matter, nuclear physics disregards weak and gravitational interactions. In some of these cases, physicists were well aware of dealing with special situations, or limiting cases as they were called in the article; in other cases, they were not. It is pointed out that, even if it were true that present-day physics accurately describes the motion of the physical constituents of living bodies, it would not give the whole story. Arguments are adduced, however, to show that the laws of physics, applicable for inanimate matter, will have to be modified when dealing with the more general situation in which life and consciousness play significant roles." From the summary. 451</page><page sequence="34">2'. Physical Sciences: Chemistry 39 c. Chemistry BAKER, A. ALBERT. Unsaturation in organic chemistry. Troisieme edition mise a jour. (Que sais-je? 35.) 127 pp., bibl., index. Panis: Presses Universitaires de France, 1969. 457 FARBER, EDUARD. Errors in chemical identification: A precautionary note to the history of chemistry. Isis, 1970, 61:379-383. While names of substances have remained constant, their purity has undergone changes of various magnitudes. The late Dr. Farber, in his last publication, offers some examples of the historical correction of errors. The scientists involved and the errors are: Abraham Alexis Boch, reduction of CO2 to HCHO and active hydrogen H3; Emil and Otto Fischer, oxidation of trinitro-triphenylmethane to the carbinol; Henri Moisson, electrolysis of redistilled HF; Otto Diels, preparation of cyanuric chloride; Albert Adampiewicz, color test for albuminates and peptones; Victor Meyer, test for benzene and the discovery of thio-phene; Friedrich Konrad Beilstein, test for Cl, Be, and I in organic substances. The examples are intended to alert us to a critical attitude toward tests and purities of reagents. G. B. KAUFFMAN 458 FARBER, EDUARD. The way from chemical principles to the principles of chemistry. Actes XIIe Cong. Int. Hist. Sci, 1968 (pub. 1971), 6:33-36. 459 GUERON, JULES; MICHEL MAGAT. A history of physical chemistry in France. A. Rev. Phys. Chem, 1971,22:1-23. 460 HARTLEY, HAROLD. Studies in the history of chemistry. xi + 243 pp., 17 plts., illus., bibl., index. London: Oxford Univ. Pr., 1971. ?2.75. An easily readable volume, intended for use in universities and the sixth form (ages 16-18), this is a collection of nine of the author's lectures delivered during the period 1933 to 1966, together with an article of 1965. Although it deals mostiy with "the formative period of chemistry during the period 1760 to 1860", it also considers events extending well into the 20th century. The approach is primarily biographical with the different chapters devoted to the immortals of chemistry, but much background material is included. G. B. KAUFFMAN 461 HASCHMI, MOHAMED YAHIA. Schneer, Mind and matter (New York, 1970). 465 KNIGHT, DAVID M. Teaching the history of chemistry to nonchemists. J. Chem Educ., 1971, 48:285-286. In teaching the history of chemistry to nonchemists, the author suggests teaching it as a branch of general intellectual history and in its relation to other aspects of history and science. He is concemed with the cosmological and meta- physical aspects of chemistry around 1800. Popular sources are utilized in the belief that those facets of chemistry which have in the past interested laymen will interest nonchemists. The approach uses case studies from chemistry to illustrate general questions in philosophy of science and attempts to find what general points contemporaries emphasized. G. B. Chikungunya and dengue: A case of mistaken identity? J. Hist. Med, 1971, 26:243-262. "The evidence uncovered [by an extensive search for early articles on the occurrence of dengue and acute fevers both in India and elsewhere] provides a good basis for believing (a) that the term 'dengue' was originally applied, in the early 19th century, to a clinical syndrome closely resembling that now associated with chikungunya virus infection, and (b) that present-day 'dengue fever' corresponds to the 'break-bone fever' described by Rush in 1789, which disease is quite distinguishable from the one that first received the name 'dengue'." 652 CHATTOPADHYAY, APARNA. "With the introduction of the horizontal-wheel water mill slightly over 400 years ago, rotaey motion was used for the first time to grind food in the previously wheelless New World. This simple mill fit well into the subsistence-oriented agriculture of the highland of Peru, Bolivia, and Ecuador wherever wheat and barley became important. Now modernization processes are again changing the milling technology of the Central Andean peasantry, triggering a series of shifts that spell the demise of this ancient device." 782 GILLE, BERTRAND. Technology 57 JEFIMENKO, OLEG; DAVID K. WALKER. Electro- static motors. Physics Teacher, 1971, 9:121-129. Discussion of "electrostatic motors" which make direct use of electrostatic attraction and repulsion, and their develop- ment from the earliest as conceived by Benjamin Franklin in 1748 to modem motors containing electrets, or permanently polarized dielectrics. Includes descriptions and diagrams of motors introduced by Benjamin Franklin, J. C. Poggendorff (1870), William McVay (1891), the Russians Yu. Karpov, V. Krasnoperov, Yu. Okunev (1958), J. D. N. Van Wyck and G. J. Kuhn (1961), B. Sujak and W. Heffner (1963), and electrets first made by the Japanese physicist Eguchi (1919) and used in electrostatic motors by Russian physicist A. N. Med., 1971, 26:3-17. "It seems clear that much effort and ingenuity has gone into the establishment of disease hypotheses which lack sufficient evidence. The goal seemed attractive: to explain Akhenaton's behavior, his revolutionary actions in the religious and political arena, as stemming from a progressive and inexorable disease. This view has perhaps unwittingly contributed to the idea that the Pharaoh's reforms were odd or abnormal. It has obscured religious, socio-economic, and psychological factors operative in the pre-Amarna era, which may well have played decisive roles in shaping Akhenaton's ideas in his formative years. The case should rest until new historical and archeological know- ledge becomes available about this dramatic age ir. ancient Egyptian history." 882 WEEKS, KENT R. Ideas, 1971, 32:163-184. "The purpose of this article is to elucidate and distinguish clearly among the Renaissance theories of art and nature, by tracing them back to the ancient contexts in which Renaissance philosophers, theorists, and writers learnt them. A central premise of this article is that however these theories were modified and elaborated in their translation from antiquity to the Renaissance, the basic presuppositions con- tained in them, and the important distinctions and divisioiis which one can perceive amnong them in classical antiquity, hold good in the Renaissance." Particular attention is givets to Plato, Aristotle, and Plotinus. 894 COX, A. S. "This essay is concerned with the antecedents of Aristotle's bipartite or moral psychology. It considers two common theses: (1) Aristotle's bipartite psychology is in origin a popular psychology already present. . . in Euripedes Medea and Hippolytus; (2) Aristotle's bipartite psychology developed out of tripartition by collapsing together the lower elements of tripartition. Roughly, I shall be qualifying the first and rejecting t:tc second thesis." 897 FREDE, DOROTHEA. Theophrasts Kritik am unbewegten Beweger des Aristoteles. Whereas the most important roots of the conception 'hallucination' lie in the Middle Ages and the Renaissance ...the concept of image has its main roots in the writings of the ancient Greek philosophers, poets, medical men, etc." 904 KERFERD, G. "The discussion of the soul in Epicurus' Letter to Herodotus ...rasses two major problems of interpretation, that of the structure of the soul, and that of its distribution and manner of functioning in relation to the body." 905 LAFRANCE, YVON. F42. 912 O'BRIEN, DENIS. The effect of simile: Empedocles' theories of seeing and breathing. J. Hellenic Stud., 1970, 90:140-179. "A curious irony hangs over the two similes of the lantern and the clepsydra which Empedocles used to describe his theories of seeing and breathing ... Similes were a feature of Empedocles style, and it is clear that on these two in particular he has lavished considerable care. They have been preserved in their entirety, as almost the longest continuous quotations which Aristotle makes from any author. Despite such auspicious beginning, these two similes have proved peculiarly resistant to modern attempts at interpretation. The reason for this, I thall try to show, is that certain features in the two similes took on a spurious significance as a result of Plato's remodel- ling of Enmpedocles' theories. Difficulties of interpretation have been caused by trying to read back these innovations of Platonic theory into details of the similes that in their original context were fortuitous and inessential." 913 POHLMANN, EGERT. Der Mensch - das Mangelivesen? Zum Nachwirken antiker Anthro- pologie bei Arnold Gehlen. Arch. Kulturgesch., 1970, 52:297-3 12. 914 REGEN, FRANK. Apuleius philosophus Platonicus. Centaurus, 1970, 15:113-123. "In MetaphYSics, in the course of his development of the theosy of God, Aristotle digresses somewhat in order to descnibe the astronomical system of Eudoxiss and Callipus. After describing this system, Aristotle points out a certain defect in it and then goes on to correct this defect. In order to accomplish this he increases the number of celestial spheres from 33 to 35. My purpose here is to analyse the factors which probably prompted Aristotle to consider the system of the mathematicians as inadequate." 930 BICKNELL, PETER J. Early Greek knowledge of the planets. Refers especially to errors in the history of ancient mathematics. 935 BURSTYN, HAROLD L. The empirical basis of the four elements. Actes XIIe Cong. Int. Hist. ScL, 1968 (pub. 1971), 3a:19-24. "This paper suggests that, rather than offering a theory of matter (as the alchemists assumed), what Empedocles and Aristotle were doing was to describe the arrangement of materials on the planet earth and the gross geological phenomena whirh result from their motions under gravity. Viewed in this light, the Greek theory of matter and motion is a generalization of simple observation." 936 CONDOS, THEONY. "Roughly speaking, the first problem concems why Plato constructed the faces of the polyhedral particles in the manner which he relates rather than in any of a number of ways which might aspear to be simpler or more economical. In particular, why did he choose the half-square and half- equilateral triangle as his elements rather than the full fiures? The second problem consists of a set of closely related questions concerning the explicitly omitted reason why Plato regarded his triangular elements as the 'best' right triangles and why he grouped them in sets of four and six, respectively, rather than in pairs in order to form the fun figures." 961 REIDY, MARTIN F. Followed (pp. 260-269) by comments by Edward Grant and John E. Murdoch. 1108 DRAKE, STILLMAN. Bradwardine's function, mediate denomination, and multiple continua. Physis, 1970, 12:51-68. Summary. - It is shown that Bradwardine in his general rule relating ratios of velocities to force-resistance ratios did not consider fractional components. The so-called"Bradwardine's function" exhibits as a continuous function what was intended as a rule of selection for commensurable ratios under a medi- eval theory of proportionality recognizing more than one distinct continuum. "Mediate" denomination is related to the concept of the geometric mean under that theory of proport- ionality. 1109 EASTWOOD, BRUCE S. Uses of geometry in medieval optics. Actes XIIe Cong. Int. Hist. BOLZAN' La Summa physicorum atribuida a Roberto Grosseteste. Sapientia, 1971, 26:21-74. 1124 LINDBERG, DAVID C. Bacon, Witelo, and Pecham: The problem of influence. Actes XIIe Cong. Int. Hist. Sci, 1968 (pub 1971), 3a:103-107. Contends that Witelo was influenced by Bacon's optical works, and suggests a possible mechanism of transmission. A direct quotation is presented as evidence either that Witelo knew Pecham' work or that Pecham knew Witelo's work, the later alternative being the more probable. 1125 LINDBERG, DAVID C. Lines of influence in 13th-century optics: Bacon, Witelo, and Pecham. Speculum, 1971,46:66-83. "I am interested in determining not only who influenced whom, but also by what means that influence was exercised. Thus I have not considered it sufficient to demonstrate that Witelo knew Bacon's optical works, which one can do from intemal evidence alone, but I have also attempted to understand the external circumstances by which Witelo gained access to Bacon's works. I have there- fore found it necessary to consider questions of physical location, the dating of works, and possible avenues of com- munication. This concern with the external circumstances of Bacon, Witelo, and Pecham confers significant benefits. It sheds light on their lives, the conditions under which they worked, and the degree to which they were members of a scientific community; by allowing us to to see beyond the conceptual aspects of their work-to see them as more than disembodied minds-it reveals several of the human and social aspects of mediaeval science. Moreover, this external approach teaches us something about the dissemination of scientific literature in the thirteenth century; in particular, it leads to the surprising conclusion that the papal court in Viterbo, in part fortuitously and in part through the activity of William of Moerbeke, served as a center' for the trans- mittal of optical literature in the 1260's and 1270's." 1126 LUCAS, ROBERT A. Prolegomena to Byrthferth's Manual. Diss. Abs. Int., 1971, 31:6559-A. Dissertation at Univ. Illinois,Urbana-Champaign, 1970. Univ. Microfilms order no. 71-14850. 197 pp. $4 fim; $10 xerox. "It is evident that Latini la 13th-century Florentine] knew of the dual polarity of the magnet and appreciated that in thick weather sailors might mistake the ends if they were not careful. It would seem possible that Latini had heard of the Southem Cross but was under the impression that like the pole Star it would occupy the southern pole of the heavens. It is an indication of the tidiness that early scientists seem to have expected always to find in the universe." 1173 REBORA, GIOVANNI (ed.) Un manule di tintoria del Quattrocento. "It is hoped that this paper [may suggest] the modifications -amounting at times, to distortions-that the moisture- idea experienced in being fitted to the varied analytical schemes of medieval medical theory. Our subject has an added interest, moreover, because of its significance for the history of that most stubborn and central of scientific questions, namely: in what kinds and configurations of matter is it possible for life to appear?" Summary.- This paper reports the contents of a treatise written by a Spanish Arab resident in North Africa in the 12th century. The treatise describes an equatorium invented by the author, an instrument for predicting planetary longitudes. This particular example fits into the tradition of such instruments, the first known having originated in Muslim Spain, although most of the equatoria now extant were constructed later, in Western Europe. 1258 al-KINDI. "Zur Zeit des Kalifen al-Mutawakkil (847-861) uibersetzte ein syrischer Christ namens Stephanos, Sohn des Basileios, das gesamte Werk aus dem Griechischen ins Arabische, und diese bersetzung, von Hunain ibn Is4aq, dem Haupt der Baghdader Ubersetzerschule, durchgesehen, verbessert und approbiert, bildete fortan die Grundlage der umfangreichen, nur zum Teil erhaltenen pharrmakologischenjLiteratur des islamischen Mittelalters. Die Geschichte dieser Ubersetzung und ihrer weiteren Bearbeitung durch spanisch-arabische Gelehrte erze8lt uns ein spanischer Arzt des 10. Jahrhunderts, Sulaiman ibn Hassan, genannt Ibn (ulgul. Dieser Bericht ist in neuerer Zeit mehrfach untersucht, aber nicht immer richtig verstanden worden." 1283 FALK, ZEEV. Problemes medicaux dans le droit Hebraique et Israelien. Revue Hist. Med. Opera. With an intro. by Richard H. Popkin. 2 vols., illus., port. Hildesheim: Olms, 1970. Facsimile reprint. 1349</page><page sequence="83">88 36. Renaissance: General BIDWELL, JAMES K.; BERNARD K. LANGE. Girolamo Cardano: A defense of his character. Maths Teacher, 1971, 64:25-31. "We have attempted to defend the character and ability of Cardano not only by examining the claims of various writers in the light of 16th-century moral and intellectual values but also by referring to his own arguments. Clearly, the erroneous statements made concerning Cardano's character originate from ethical systems very different from that in which Cardano functioned. It is our opinion that careless judgements concerning the scope and quality of his works as well as his ability as a mathe- niatician are in many cases rooted in this prejudging of Cardano's character. Thus Girolamo Cardano has been maligned and castigated unfairly by many modem writers who have perpetuated old arguments without careful investigation." 1350 BOIANOV, SLAVI I. Concentrates on the neoplatonic and Hermetic influences on SCrvctus' tlicology. 1363 GODINE, DAVID R.; OWEN GINGERICH. Renaissance books of science, from the collection of Albert E. Lownes. 123 pp., illus. Hanover: Dartmouth College, 1970. Catalog of an exhibition. 1364</page><page sequence="84">36. Renaissance: General 89 KEARNEY, HUGH F. Science and change, 1500- 1700. 253 pp., plts., illus., bibl., index. London: Weidenfeld and Nicolson; New York: McGraw-Hill, 1971. ?1.75. This book will be an attractive text for history of science surveys, with its readable style and interesting illustrations. The author denounces "Whig history" and prefers instead to see the Scientific Revolution as a process of interaction of three competing traditions or paradigms: organic, magical, and iniechanical. Adherents to the organic (Aristotelian) tradition include Harvey and perhaps- Francis Bacon. The magical (Hermetic, neoPlatonic, Pythagorean) tradition inspired Copernicus, Kepler, Bruno, and Gilbert. Galileo initiated the transition from magical to mechanical, the latter viewpoint being of course primarily associated with Descartes and Boyle, while Newton is seen as the synthesizer of magical and mechanical traditions. These interpretations will of course be challenged by historians who favor other categories, but Kearney's book is at least a good example of how a simple framework can be used to relate science to its cutural setting. The most serious defect of the book is that the author seems to have very little understanding of the scientific content of the works he mentions; thus Newton is dismissed in about 8 pages, mostly devoted to justifying his identification with the magical tradition. In the end the reader gets nothing but a very superficial indication of the reasons why the Scientific Revolution deserves its name. S. G. BRUSH 1365 KEMPFI, ANDRZEJ. Erazm a zycie intelektualne na Warmii w czasach Mikojaja Kopernika. (Erasmus and intellectual life in Warmia during the times of Copernicus.) Kwart. Hist. Nauki Tech., 1970, 15:743-758. Concemed especially with Tiedemann Giese. 1366 KRISTELLER, PAUL OSKAR. The contribution of religious orders to Renaissance thought and leaming. Amr Benedictine Rev., 1970,21:1-55. Appendix A contains a list of libraries of religious orders, appendix B a list of humanists and scholars of religious orders. 1367 KUZNETSOV, BORIS GRIGOR'EVICH. Styl Giordana Bruno. (Bruno's literary style.) Kwart. list. Nauki Tech, 1971, 16:317-326. Examines Bruno's style as an influence on his scientific ideas. 1369 LEONARDO DA VINCI. "In his Livre d'arithmeticque, edited at Antwerp in 1561, Valentin Mennher set 100 problems on arithmetic and trigo- nometry, followed by the 'facit'. It was known that Michel Coignet wrote a treatise on these problems under the title Cent questiones ingenieuses, Antwerp 1573, but there was only one copy of the book known, located at the University of Louvan. This library was burmt down in 1914. 1 discovered a copy of the booklet in the Museum Plantin Moretus, Antwerp." From the English summary. 1384 DESTOMBES, MARCEL. Copernicus and Renaissance astronomy. Pp. 95-105 in Robert Schwoebel (ed.) Renaissance men and ideas. New York: St. Martin's Pr., 1971. 1408 ROSEN, EDWARD. Copernicus' attitude toward the common people. J. Hist. Ideas, 1971, 32:281-288. 1409 ROSEN, EDWARD. Mikolaj Kopernik nie byl Ksiedzem. (Copernicus was not apriest!) Kwart. Hist. Nauki Tech , 1970, 15:729-737. Translated from English. Summary: Copernicus was never ordained a priest. Nevertheless, at three different times in history, he was falsely described as a priest. The first perpetrator of this deception was Galileo; the second was an erratic Polish historian; and the third was an Italian archivist, who deliberately altered a notarial document which he had discovered. Another document, found more recently, provides absolutely decisive confirmation that the contemporaries of Copernicus were aware that he was not a priest. The attempt by a German scholar to cast doubt on this historical certainty by misrepresenting this new document is here examined in detadl and refuted. 1410 ROSEN, EDWARD. Rheticus' earliest extant letter to Paul Eber. Isis, 1970, 61:384-386. Followed by a commentary by Karl Heinz Burmeister. 1411 RUKEYSER, MURIEL. The traces of Thomas Hariot. "It is generally agreed that between 1746 and 1749 Diderot changed his position from being a deist to becoming an atheist ... What appears to have received little or no attention hitherto is, notwithstanding, a strikingly character- istic feature of this change. Whereas in the Pensees philosophiques [1746] Diderot employed the physical sciences to prove the existence of God, by 1749 he was using the life sciences to establish an atheistic position." 1599 KODALLE, KLAUS-M. "In einer Situation der Wissenschaft, da Theorie der Sprache sich anschickt, zur scientia prima zu avancieren, kann es nicht schaden, an einen Protagonisten dieser Entwicklunq, Thomas Hobbes (1588 bis 1679), zu erinnern. Findet sich doch bei diesem der Primat philosophischer Reflexion auf Sprache in einer Weise entfaltet, welche zugleich den Blick auf aporetische Implikationen eines solchen Primats freigibt, sofem er auf dem Boden des modemen, an den exakten mathematischen Wissenschaften gewonnenen Wissenschafts- begriffes entfaltet wird. Um die spezifische Position des Hobbes angemessen bestimmen zu konnen, erscheint es angebracht, einige allgemeine Bemerkungen zur Sprachtheorie voranzuschicken." 1600 KOPPER, JOACHIM. L 1000. 1665 VUGS, J. G. Steno in Amsterdam. Janus, 1970, 57:163-172. 1666 WALTON, CRAIG. Ramus and Bacon on method. J. Hist. Phil., 1971, 9:289-302. "My present aim is to show that two chief elements of Bacon's mature writings were chief elements in Ramus' work, and that they were developed by Bacon in ways remarkably close to those of Ramus. The two elements are: 1) the definition of and distinction between 'invention' and 'judgment'; and 2) a shift of emphasis from formal causes as static definitions of substances and properties to articulation of operative principles as interdependent variables in explanation ... I shall conclude with some observations as to how the similarities and differences between Ramus and Bacon indicate the dimension of the struggle to find a method of inquiry at once grounded in natural human capabilities yet safeguarded from the follies and sterilities of the past." 1667 WARR, NANCY N. "Der Nachlass der Helmstedter Gelehrtendynastie Meibom befsndet sich heute in der Niedersschsischen Landesbibliothek zu Hannover und in der Universitatsbibliothek zu Gottingen. Zum Nachlass gehoren Hinterlassenschaften aller vier Generationen der Helmstedter Professorenfamilie Meibom. Insbesondere von dem Historiker Heinrich Meibom sen. (1555-1625) und von den Medizinem Johann Heinrich Meibom (1590-1655) und Heinrich Meibom jr. (1638-1700), aber auch von dem Mediziner Brandanus Meibom (1678- 1740). Der Nachlass besteht aus Autographen der Professoren Meibom, Konzepten und Handschriften ihrer Werke, den ausgedehnten Korrespondenzen mit Zeitgenossen vom 16. bis zum 18. Jahrhundert und einer grosseren Zahl von llandschriften und Kopien historischer, medizinischer, theologischer und philologischer Autoren. lnsgesamt handelt es sich um Handschriften und Autographen in 530 Banden bzw. Konvoluten, davon 355 in Hannover und 175 in Gottingen. Auch wesentliche Teile der Meibomschen Privatbibliotheken mit einer grossen Zahl wertvoller Drucke aus mehreren Jahrhunderten gehoren zum Nachlass." 1671 WERNER, STEPHEN D. "I want to discuss why the geometrical approach of [Robert] Simson and [Colin] MacLaurin continued to provide the pattem for almost all Scottish mathematical works during the late 18th and early 19th century in spite of a widespread belief among Scottish mathematicians and natural philosophers that analytic mathematical techniques were frequently more powerful than those of classical geometry. Fundamentally, I hope to demonstrate that the epistomological doctrines associated with the Common Sense Philosophy of Thomas Reid and Dugald Stewart not only reinforced an appreciation of geometrical reasoning, but also provided a significant obstacle to the acceptance of analytical methods by S&gt;ottish mathematicians." 1698 ROCHOT, B. Sky Telesc., 1971,42:344-345. Speculations on the nature of the fifth object. 1713 BAIRD, A. S. W. Pascal's idea of nature. Isis, 1970, 61:297-320. "In his study of Blaise Pascal's contemporary Marin Mersenne, the Abbe Lenoble distinguishes between the idea of nature as an active principle, which Aristotelian physics has as its object, and nature viewed as an ensemble de phenomenes, with which mechanistic physics is 'correlative'. Pascal ... is not conitent simply to relegate the former conception to the realm of metaphysics and reduce the scope of physical science to investigating and describing the empirical connections between the phenomena which go to make up nature in the second sense. On the coestrary, in Pascal's case, which does not seem as clear-cut, the term nature, construed as an active principle, is found in a wide variety of contexts throughout his writings. This is not to say that Pascal believes it is nature as an active principle that physical science is concerned with. But it does suggest that his curiously ambivalent attitude to the mechanistic worid view may result in part from a conviction that it fails to take account of this aspect of nature." 1714 BECKMAN, ANNA. Anders Celsius och den hundragradiga termometerskalan. (Celsius and the centigrade thermometer.) Lychnos, 1969-1970: 340.347. 1715 BERNARD-MAITRE, HENRI. De kleurentheorie van Christiaan Huygens. Scientiarum Hist., 1970, 12:143-158. "This article deals with Huygens' view on the theories of colours, as proposed by Hooke and Newton. The opinion of Huygens was dominated by a mechanistic conception of physical theories, especially on light, and his particular vision on the relation between hypothesis and experiment. Huygens was much more occupied with experimental work on colours than usually accepted. This article indicates that Huygens was the first to find the relation between the colours of inter- ference and the thickness of the plates. The definition of colours by their frequency, as proposed by Newton, was not accepted by Huygens because of his special conception of light." From the English summary. 1721 BRUNET, PIERRE. L'introduction des theories de Newton en France au XVIIIe si6cle. Avant 1738. vii + 355 pp., bibl. Geneva: Slatkine Reprints, 1970. Robert Hooke's contribution to mechanics: A study in 17th-century natural philosophy. xiii + 136 pp., bibl., index. The Hague: Nijhoff, 1970. Fl 18. 1728 CHALDECOTT, J. A. The bulk fusion of platinum: Early experiments by Lavoisier and Seguin. Platin. Metals Rev., 1970, 14(1):24-28. Soon after the French Academy of Sciences in 1789 began to draw up plans for the establishment of a uniform system of weights and measures, it was suggested that standards for the new measures of length and of weight, when determined, should be executed in platinum. Since ordinary methods of heating were inadequate to melt platinum, Lavoisier, Meusnier, and Seguin began work on a furnace, the fire of which was made intense by feeding it with a stream of oxygen. Their work is described in a diary of 1791 kept by the Scottish geochemist, Sir James Hall. The work was apparently unlstuccessful. G. B. KAUFFMAN 1729 COHEN, I. BERNARD. Introduction to Newton's Principia. xxviii + 380 pp., plts., bibl., index. Cambridge: Harvard Univ. Pr., 1971. $30. Notre propos, modeste, est simplement de montrer que la fin du Scholie qui termine le preambule des Principia, apres la definition VIII, ne peut pas etre comprise sans cet exercise rigoureux. L'enjeu est d'importance puisqu'il s'agit de savoir, d'apres la d6claration de l'auteur lui-meme, s'il y a lieu d'esperer que des experiences de mecaniq,ue soient revelatrices des mouvements absolus, en privilegiant a cet egard les rotations." 1733 A COUNTRY curate. "First I want to examine some rather curious arguments of Kant's which purport to show that some alleged properties of space can be derived from some alleged facts about incon- gruous counterparts. Secondly, I want to give some pre- liminary answers to some important questions about the distinction between right and left and the nature of space and space-tiune which are raised by Kant's argument. As a by- product, I hope that the discussion will provide an example of how science can illuminate philosophical issues and how phlilosophy can at least lead one into interesting scientific issues." 1741</page><page sequence="103">108 37. 1 7th &amp; 18th Centuries: Physical Sciences FICHMAN, MARTIN. "The collaboration between Lavoisier and Laplace is generally known only through their joint 'Memoire sur la chaleur' of 1783, but it began six years earlier ... I have tried to trace the main steps in the collaboration between these two giants of science, and above all to show what role this collaboration played in, and what the experiments on heat contributed to, the full and confident elaboration of Lavoisier's theory of combustion and his major assaults on the citadel of the older chemistry." 1762</page><page sequence="104">37. 17th &amp; 18th Centuries: Physical Sciences 109 HANZAL, JOSEF. Leibniz and the vis viva controversy. Isis, 1971, 62:21-35. "We are ... able to view Leibniz's attack on the Cartesian measure of force as primarily an attempt to establish his own philosophical system based on the conservation of 'force' and to place less emphasis on a simple attempt to substitute the mathematical formula mv2 for the formula m I v I. This latter aim is encompassed in the more general purpose of the former. Perhaps his insight into a universe which was fundamentally energistic led him to make assumptions about the possibility of transferring that energy and to identify implicitly the conservation and the measure of force, the establishment of both being an integral part of his ultimate aim." 1769 JAQUEL, ROGER. "This study argues the particular progressiveness of the University of Leiden in accommodating itself to the Scientific Revolution of the 17th century. More general concerns of the study pertaini to the philosophic challenge occasioned by the new science and to the university and pedagogical traditions that obstructed a fuller appreciation of that science. The primary sources consist of the teachings and writings of a succession of professors in philosophy at Leiden - Franco Burgersdijck, Albert Kijper, Adriaan Heereboord, Joannes de Raey, Arnold Geulincx, Burchaldus de Volder and Wolferdus Senguerdius." 1812 SADOUN-GOUPIL, MICHELLE. Galileo and the controversy of the comets (1618-1623). Physis, 1970, 12: 5-35. "It is argued in this paper that Galileo's refusal to admit the physical existence of comets was prompted by the serious threat Tycho's system represented to his heliocentric theory. The controversy between Galileo and Orazio Grassi also illustrates how observational reports and experiments are often prejudged in the light of varying theories." 1825 SHEA, WILLIAM R. Galileo, Scheiner, and the interpretation of sunspots. Isis, 1970, 61:498-518. "We shall be mainly concerned with the methodological assumptions that guided the research of Galileo and Scheiner, but since it is indispensable to see the problems in their historical setting, the introductory section of this paper will be devoted to a summary of the successive phases of the debate leading to the publication of Galileo's Letters on the sunspots in 1613. In the second section, Galileo's assump- tions will be compared with those of Scheiner, and the respective merits and shortcomings of their approaches will be discussed with particular reference to the role of observation and the relevance of mathematics." 1826 SHEA, WILLIAM R. Isis, 1970, 61:188-205. "Important historical questions therefore hinge on Newton's work on diffraction. What, precisely, is meant by the claim that Newton missed the observation of the interior inter- ference fringes? Is it probable that Newton would have embraced the wave theory if he had observed these fringes? In an attempt to answer these questions, I shall first examine the most important of Newton's writings on diffraction; secondly, I shall analyse Newton's diffraction experiments; and finally, I shall attempt to determine the influence of these experimcnts on Newton's views on the nature of light." 1834 SZOKEFALVI-NAGY, ZOLTAN. "By 1750 [the Royal Society] saw itself clearly as an instrument for promoting natural knowledge but not as an encourager of arts, manufactures, and commerce in a practical way. The Society of Arts was founded in 1754 for this very purpose, and there is reason to believe that about the year 1755 there was an unofficial agreement that the Royal Society should concern itself with pure science and leave the application of it to this newly-formed society. Of the diligence of the Society of Arts in trying to fulfil their purpose there can be no question . .. but it is doubtful whether they met with the success they deserved." The first three parts of this paper appeared inAnn. Sce, 1963, 19:183-237; 1964, 20: 1-57; 1965, 21:81-130, 175-201. 1841 TRESSE, RENE. La jeunesse et l'initiation du mecanicien Claude-Pierre Molard de 1759-1791. Revue Hist. Sci. Applic., 1971, 24:13-24. 1842 TURNER, GERARD L'E. James Short and the reflecting telescope. Actes XIIe Cong. Int. Hist. Sci., 1968 (pub. 1971), 1Oa: 101-106. 1843</page><page sequence="108">37. 1 7th &amp; 18th Centuries: Physical Sciences, Earth Sciences 113 TURNER, GERARD L'E. Mr. James Short, optician, founding member of the Society. J. R. Soc. Arts, 1970, 118:788-792. 1844 VAN HELDEN, ALBERT. Eustachio Divini versus Christiaan Huygens: A reappraisal. Physics, 1970, 12:36-50. Summary: The publication, in 1659, of Systema saturnium, the tract in which Christiaan Huygens proposed his theory that the planet Saturn was surrounded by a ring which accounted for all the strange appearances that had baffled observers for 50 years, led to a polemical exchange between Huygens and Honore Fabri and Eustachio Divini. While Fabri proposed his own theory to explain the appearances of Saturn, Divini attacked Huygens' observations and defended his own telescopes which he felt had been condemned by implication by Huygens. Both Divini and Huygens argued for the superiority of their telescopes. With the acceptance of Huygens' ring-hypothesis, his telescopes were assumed to be better than those of Divini. This paper shows that although it is possible that this was in fact the case, an examination of the evidence shows that there is plenty of reason to doubt this supposition and that Divini has not been treated fairly by his contemporaries and by historians. 1845 VELLUZ, LEON. Le Pasteur Priestley. 188 pp., plts., bibl. Paris: Plon, 1968. F 27. 1846 VIGLIONE, A. Science, religion and society for Paolo Frisi. Scientia, 1970, 105:621-629. "Paolo Frisi (1728-1784) was a Milanese monk, educator and scientist. Despite the fact that he was a monk, his major interest in life was science. Science for Frisi was not only useful but it was also a way of life. Although science need not have a justification for existing, it nonetheless was one of the ways of obtaining knowledge of truth which is a manifestation of Divinity. Hence God could be perceived by science as well as by religion, for truth is one . . . " From the summary. 1847 WAGNER, FRITZ. Isaac Newtons Friedenstraum. Astro., 1971, 2:35-41. Heinrich Schultz's proposal, brought to London in 1762, was to fmd longitude at sea by observations of the moon's meridian transits. 1872 FORBES, ERIC G. Who discovered longitude at sea? Sky Telesc., 1971, 41:4-6. Discussion of the contributions of Tobias Mayer and John Harrison to the discovery of longitude at sea. The author concludes that "the method of lunar distances, its practical application, and its general use in navigation all take precedence chronologically over the corresponding stages in the development of the rival chronometer method. From this standpoint Mayer, not Harrison, might justifiably be regarded as the first man who discovered longitude at sea.' 1873 FRANGSMYR, TORE. L'oeuvre astronomique du pere Feuillee a fait l'objet de deux etudes en 1846 et 1896; par contre, ses travaux consacres a la botanique et i la matiure medicale n'ont fait l'objet jusqu'ici d'aucune etude approfondie, bien que leur apport fut loin d'6tre negligeable. Linne, par exemple, place le pere Feutille parmi les restauratores et n'hesite pas a debaptiser le genre .Vhandiroba de Plumier pour en faire le genre Fevillea L'auteur a puise l'essentiel de sa documentation dans les dix volumes in-folio des manuscrits du pere Feuillee, ainsi que dans divers manuscrits provenant les uns de Versailles, les autres du depot de la Marine ou des Augustins reformes, manuscrits longtemps consideres comme definitivement perdus. "The thesis of this dissertation is that Descartes' doctrine of the relation of mind to body cannot be clearly grasped unless due weight is given to the ambiguous character of his use of the term 'body'. This dissertation thus calls attention to the crucial imp)ortance of physiological investigations as the main justification for much that otherwise appears strained and irrational in the Cartesian writers." 1915 CHAUVOIS, LOUIS. "Sur ce fonds, nous avons mene un double travail, encore que les deux niveaux en soient lies: 1. Exploitationp ar ordinateur (IBM 1620, puis Univac 1108) d'un fichier epidemiologique, constitu6 a partir des tables imprim6es et publies de 1779 a 1789 (pour l'etat des maladies de 1776 a 1786) par les soins de Vicq-d'Azyr, et qui resument i l'extreme certaines des correspondances reques ("tableaux"). Ces donnees se revelant insuffisantes en nombre comme en precision furent com- pletees grace i la mise en fiches des tableaux et memoires qui, dans le fonds manuscrit, s'y pretaient. 2. Depouillement des sources manuscrites de toute nature, permettant d'acquerir les connaissances indispensables sur l'cnvironnement institutionnel, et surtout sur le systeme de l'ancienne medecine. Ce travail a servi, sur le plan particulier de l'etablissement du programme d'ordinateur, i risoudre les problimes poses par le fichier (lacunes, obscurites nosologiques). C'est lui, surtout, qui nous met en mesure de presenter des faits et quelques reflexions touchant i l'univers de la maladie, aux representations de la vie et de la mort chez les malades pauvres et chez leurs therapeutes, i la fm du XVIIlF siecle." 2114 PETRELLI, RICHARD L. "An example of the rapid and complete transit of technology from a developed to an underdeveloped area ... is afforded by the transit of technology from Britain to its N. American colonies during the 17th and 18th centuries. Several factors L.count for this easy and successful transit of technology: 1) the craft level of Bfitish technology which made it trans- ferable without complicated machinery or large capital investment; 2) the need for simple craft technology in a virgin land; 3) the receptivity of the American colonists, who possessed the same cultural background as the British." 2155 KROKER, WERNER. "In so far then as it is possible to talk about a process of unification, that process was a complex and subtle affair, and one which must not be identified with the increasing sophistication of systematic organic synthesis. Henry Brougham and the Scottish methodological tradition. Stud. Hist. Phil Sci, 1971, 2:69-89. "The first part of this paper deals with the wider issues of the Scottish methodological tradition-a tradition which encompassed the writings not only of the natural philosophers such as Black, Robison, Playfair, Brougham, Leslie and Brewster, but also of the moral philosophers, including Hume, Reid, Stewart and Brown. In the second section the attitudes of these Scottish natural and moral philosophers towards ethereal fluids will be discussed. The final section deals specifically with Brougham; firstly, his ideas on scientific method will be examined, and then these commitments will be related to his attacks on Young." 2314 CARDWELL, DONALD S. L. From Watt to Clausius: The rise of thermodynamics in the early industrial age. xv + 336 pp., plts., illus., bibl., index. Ithaca, N. Y.: Comell Univ. Pr., 1971. $11.50. 2315 CASSEBAUM, HEINZ. Die Stellung der Arbeiten von J. B. Dumas (1800-1884) und A. Strecker (1822-1871) in der Entwicklung des Periodensystems. NTM, 1971, 8(l):46-57. 2316 CAUSEY, ROBERT L. Avogadro's hypothesis and the Duhemian pitfall. J. Chem Educ., 1971, 48:365-367. The author reviews the role of several chemists in the history of the delayed acceptance of Avogadro's hypothesis in the light of what he calls the "Duhemian Pitfall . (If an hypo- thesis H is in fact true, and one or more auxiliary hypotheses are false, then a scientist may obtain a negative observational result and conclude (mistakenly) that H has been falsified by the experiment.) Chemists who became trapped in this pitfall in connection with Avogardro's hypothesis include John Dalton, Jons Jacob Berzelius, A. M. Amp6re, J. B. A. Dumas, and M. A. A. Gaudin. Physicists, who were trymg to develop a general theory of gases, were less concemed than chemists with detailed chemical data and therefore less concemed with the auxiliary hypotheses and less likely to become ensnared in the pitfall. G. B. KAUFFMAN 2317 COSTA, ALBERT B. Arthur Michael (1853-1942): The meeting of thermodynamics and organic chemistry. J. Chem Educ., 1971,48:243-246. Michael incorporated the advances of physical chemistry, especially thermodynamics, into organic chemistry in order to deepen structural theory. His novel contribution to chemical theory was to introduce the thermodynamic con- cepts of free energy and entropy into organic structural theory in order to ovezeome the pictorial and mechanical interpretation of chemical behavior. Throughout his long career, he was a sharp and penetrating critic of accepted views. His superb experimental work and theoretical speculations engaged the attention of the world's chemists at the turn of the century, when he was regarded as the foremost American chemical theorist. G. B. KAUFFMAN 2318 CROSLAND, MAURICE P. Comte and Berthollet: A philosopher's view of chemistry. Actes XIIe Cong. Int. Hist. Sci, 1968 (pub. 1971), 6:23-27. 2319 CURIE, PIERRE. On the formation of crystals and on the capillary constants of their different faces. Trans. by Cecil J. Schneer. J. Chemi Educ., 1970, 47:636-637. A translation of an article by Pieree Curie (Bull Soc. Fr. Mineral., 1885, 8:145), which derives J. W. Gibbs' conditions for thermodynamic equilibrium for a crystal surface (1878) from Gauss' pnrnciple of virtual velocities. It is a point of departure for G. Wulff's (1901) classical experiments on crystal growth measuring relative capillary constants. Wulff's theorem in tum was proven by von Laue in 1943. G. B. KAUFFMAN 2320 CUVAJ, CAMILLO. Note on Poincare and relativity. Am. J. Phys, 1970,38:774-775. 2321 DANZER, KLAUS. Zur historischen Entwicklung der Emissionsspektralanalyse, insbesondere im Hinblick auf ihre Anwendung in der Praxis. Teil II. NiM, 1970, 7(1):33-45. 2322 DAUB, EDWARD E. Entropy and dissipation. Historia Stud Phys. Sci, 1970,2:321-354. "I will first consider the controversy between Clausius and the British, especially between Clausius and Tait. I will then turn to the evolution of the concepts of dissipation and irreversible entropy. I will show that Tait did make some earlier efforts to be genuinely fair to Clausius, that William Thomson committed a glaring faux pas with his blanket approval of Tait's treatment of energy dissipation, that Clausius was the first to show the relationship between lost work and irreversible entropy increase, and, fuaslly, that both Clausius and Thomson share credit for the next major step in thermodynamic thought, the explanation of spontaneity and equilibrium as developed by J. Willard Gibbs. I will argue that, despite Gibbs's obvious preference foriClausius' over competing thermodynamic concepts, Gibbs proved to be the catalyst for the first explicit and legitimate merger of entropy and dissipation in Maxwell's final revised version of his classic work on heat." 2323 DAUB, EDWARD E. Maxwell's demon. Stud Hist. Phil. Sci, 1970, 1:213-227. 2324 DEVONS, SAMUEL. Recollections of Rutherford and the Cavendish. Physics Today, 1971, 24(12):39-45. 2325 DOLBY, RICHARD G. A. Hans Christian Orated och elektro- magnetismens fodelse-Ett 150-mrsninne. (Orsted and the birth of electromagnetism-The 150th anniversary.) Daedalus (Stockholm), 1970:13-38. 2329 ELKANA, YEHUDA. The conservation of energy: A case of simultaneous discovery? Archs Int. Hist. ScL, 1970,23:31-60. "My thesis is that the principle of energy conservation is not a case of multiple discovery but that in the span of 1840.1860 different problems were bothering different groups of people in different places, and they came up with different answers. The answers turned out to be related, until fmially in the 1860's they proved to be more than related, they tumed out to be logically derivable one from the other." 2330</page><page sequence="132">38. 19t1h &amp; 20th Centuries: Physical Sciences 1 37 ELKANA, YEHUDA. Helmholtz' "Kraft": An illustration of concepts in flux. Historical Stud Phys. Sci, 1970,2:263-298. "It is argued here that Helmholtz' paper 'On the conservation of force' serves as an illustration of a general feature of the way in which scientific concepts develop: they are in a state of flux while the scientist is struggling to clarify his thoughts; that is, while the discovery is being made. I suggest that Helmholtz believed in a vaguely formulated conservation law, and that only after he had arrived at his proof of the con- servation of 'Kraft' did he distinguish between his concepts of energy and force in our sense of the terms ... It is widely accepted that scientific theories and concepts are first vague and later specific. 'Miat I emPhasize here is that the theory and concept crystallize simultaneously out of the vague early formulations. The official view of the scientist is opposed to this position, and it was even more strongly so in the 19th century." 2331 EL'IASHEVICH, M. A. The Mendeleev periodic law, atomic spectra, and atomic structure: On the history of the physical interpretation of the periodic table of the elements. Soviet Phys. Usp., 1970, 13:1-23. 2332 EUGSTER, HANS P. The beginnings of experimental petrology. Science, 1971, 173:481489. Between 1896 and 1908, Jacobus Henricus van't Hoff, one of the founders of the new science of physical chemistry, devoted his entire professional efforts to the solution of a single problem, the mineral equilibria underlying the Permian marine salt deposits at Stassfurt, Germany, pub- lishing 52 papers with some 30 collaborators. For the first time, chemical experiments were applied in a systematic and methodical manner to the solution of a geological problem. The background, details, and importance of van't Hoff's work is considered. An answer to the question of why van't Hoff, who had made his reputation by introducing theory into the largely empirical field of chemistry, abandoned theoretical work is suggested. G. B. " 2355 HEINES. SISTER VIRGINIA. Chromatography- A history of a parallel development. CheenL Tech., 1971, 1:280-285. A brief discussion of the fractionation of crude petroleum mixtures. On Aug. 20, 1900 at the first International Petroleum Congress in Paris, David Talbot Day (1859-1925), Chief of the DivisonL of Mineral Resources of the American Geological Survey, announced his results with forcing crude oil upward through a column packed with powdered lime- stone "The Day Phenomenon"., The Congress was cited by many as "The Birthday of Chromatography" and antedated Michael Tswett's classic work of 1905. The work and apparatus of Day, Tswett, Engler and others are discussed and compared. Neither Day nor Tswett were aware of each other's work, and their achievements were practically ignored for several decades. Later developments in chromatography are mentioned. G. B. KAUFFMAN 2362 HOLT, B. W. G. Social aspects in the emergence of chemistry as an exact science: The British chemical profession. Br. J. Sociol, 1970, 21:181-199. Deals with the emergence and growth of the profession in the 19th century. 2363 HOLT, NILES R. A note on Wilhelm Ostwald's energism. Isis, 1970, 61:386-389. The author discusses Ostwald's work to discredit atomism by means of the concept of Energism, which insisted that energy rather than matter was fundamental to the universe. Together with Ernst Mach, Ostwald was the last of the major scientific figures in Germany and Austria to hold out against the atomic theory. He regarded his Energism as the ultimate monism, a unity "science of science" which would bridge not only physics and chemistry, but the physical and biological sciences as well. The two major critics of Energism, Max Planck and Emst Mach, dismissed it as useless metaphysics. G. B. KAUFFMAN 2364 HOLTON, GERALD. Einstien and the "crucial" experiment. Actes XlIe Cong. Int. To most chemists, his name conjures up thoughts of the Dulong and Petit law of atomic heats of solid elements which summarized a pattern and rendered valuable service in the fixing of atomic weights. But few seem to know much about him apart from his name." From the summary. 2366 JAFFE, BERNARD. Moseley and the numbering of the elements. xi + 178 pp., plts., illus., bibl., index. Garden City, N. ScL, 1970, 9:54-75. "In considering physical science in the Romantic period, there are two questions which must be kept distinct: the first is, What influences from the world-view of Romantics penetrated and transformed physics or chemistry? and the second, What impact did discoveries in these sciences have upon Romantics?" 2378 KNIGHT, DAVID M. The transcendental part of chemistry. Actes XIIe Cong. Int. Hist. Sci., 1968 (pub. 1971), 6:49-53. "The phrase 'the transcendental part of chemistry' was used by Humphxy Davy to describe speculation about the ultimate nature of matter ... In this paper an attempt will be made to place his ideas in their context, and to assess their utility in the laboratory." 2379 KOLOMI, RUDOLF. Studium termoelektrickych jevu od Seebeckova objevu (1821) do formulace zakona zachovani energie. (The study of thermo- electric phenomena from the discovery of T. J. Seebeck to the formulation of the laws of the con- servation and transformation of energy.) Dejiny V&amp;d Tech, 1971,4:129-149. 2380 KOPPERL, SHELDON; JOHN PARASCANDOLA. The development of the adiabatic calorimeter. J. Chem. Educ., 1971, 48:237-242. Calorimetry is a very exacting science where even relatively small errors cannot be neglected, and it is extremely important that calorimeters yield very accurate measure- ments. The adiabatic calorimeter, invented in 1849 by C. C. Person, was essentially forgotten until it was independently reintroduced more than half a century later by Theodore W. Richards at Harvard in 1905. Richards' theory of the com- pressible atom led him to undertake an extended series of investigations of thermodynamic properties, which outlasted the theory which had acted as a stimulus. The details (includ- ing diagrams) of Richards' calorimeters are discussed in con- nection with his work on heats of combustion of organic com- pounds; heats of solution of metals in acids; and specific heats, heats of dilution, and heats of neutralization of solutions of inorganic acids, bases, and salts. G. B. KAUFFMAN 2381 KRATZ, OTTO. Friedsich Konrad Beilstein, 1838- 1906. Ambix, 1971, 18:2648. "In this paper it is proposed to re-examine the theory of chemical structure, and the originality of Butlerov's contri- bution, while at the same time providing arn explanation for the irreconciled polarization between [the defenders of Butlerov and the defenders of Couper and Kekul6] in terms of their differences in philosophical thinking, and therefore of differences in their way of viewing the same phenomena." 2386 LARDER, DAVID F.; FRANK F. KLUGE. Alexander Mikhailovich Butlerov's theory of chemical structure. J. Chem. Educ., 1971,48:287-289. Russian historians have viewed Butlerov's classic paper of 1861 as the foundation stone for structural theory, while Western historians have generally credited Kekule and Couper with founding this theory. The authors consider But[erov's work from the standpoint of dialectical materialism and attempt to resolve the difference between Eastern and Western views. Butierov emphasises the dynamics of chemical change, contrasted with the statics of physical observation leading to the mechanical arrangement of the atoms in the molecule, whereas no such distinction is made by Couper or Kekul6 in 1858 or by Crum Brown in 1861. Followed (pp. 289-91) by a translation of Butierov's paper "On the chemical structure of substances". G. B. KAUFFMAN 2387 LEVERE, TREVOR H. Microfilms order no. 71-9721. 272 pp. $4 film; $10 xerox. 2393 MACKLE, HENRY; CECIL L. WILSON. Thomas Andrews (1813-1885).Endeavour, 1971, 30:8-10. This Irish chemist is usually associated with the recognition of the continuity of the gaseous and liquid states and the elucidation of the concept of critical temperature, but he was also a physical chemist of wide accomplishment and made notable contributions to thermochemistry by evaluating fundamental thermodynamic quantities with an accuracy that has stood the test of time. He also conducted galvanic studies of the action of acids on metals and investigated the consti- tution and properties of ozone. He was concerned with social problems and university education. G. B. Sudhoffs Arck, 1971,55:136-151. 2395 MAUSKOPF, SEYMOUR H. Hauy's model of chemical equivalence: Daltonian doubts exhumed. Ambic, 1970,17:182-191. "In this paper, I shall first provide some information about [Rene Just] Hauy's theory of crystal structure and its bear- ing on chemical interests. Then I shall give an account of his snodel of chemical combination in the 1806 edition of the Traite ildmentaire de physique.
