B.] Richter's work to the formulation of the concept of relative atomic weight." Attention also given to C. L. Berthollet and John Dalton. 2396 MC CORMMACH, RUSSELL. Einstein, Lorentz, and the electron theory. Historical Stud Phys SCe, 1970, 2:41-87. Traces the relations of the theorical ideals underlying Einstein's light-quantum hypothesis and his special and general relativity principles to the theoretical problems defined by the electron theory. 2397 MC CORMMACH, RUSSELL. H. A. Lorentz and the electromagnetic view of nature. Isis, 1970, 61:459497. "In this essay I have analyzed Lorentz's sucessive formulations of the electron theory, tracing the consolidation of a new dynamics through the solution of specific problems connected with the earth's absolute motion. I have shown how others responded to the problem areas Lorentz's theory made central to physics and how they modified the theory to exclude all nonelectromagnetic elements and then extrapolated it into a vision of the future universal physics. I have shown how others, responding to the same problems, laid the foundations of the quantum and relativity theories, new theoretical pro- grams that made the electromagnetic view of nature as peri- pheral as the mechanical one it had supplanted. Finally, I have indicated how the objective of the original electromag- netic view was transmuted into a broader field-theoretical ideal for all of physics." 2398</page><page sequence="136">38. 19th &amp; 20th Centuries: Physical Sciences 141 MC CREA, W. H. Doubts about Mach's principle. Nature, 1971,230:95-97. "The purpose of this article is to suggest that Mach's principle in any simple fonn is largely illusory, although it is difficult to give it a meaning in any more sophisticated fonn. The possible novelty of the argument presented in the first part is that it gives a simple physical reason for the apparent connexion between local inertial properties and remote matter in the universe." 2399 MEHRA, JAGDISH. Some observations on Maxwell's Treatise on electricity and magnetism: On the role of the 'dynamical theory of the electro- magnetic field' in Part IV of the Treatise. Stud Hist. Phil Sci, 1970,1:249-263. 2425 SNELDERS, H. A. M. The influence of the dualist system of Jakob Joseph Winterl (1732-1809) on the German romantic era. Isis, 1970, 61:231-240. In a book of 1800 Prolusions ad chemiam saeculi decimi noni, the Hungarian chemist Winterl rejected the oxidation theory of Lavoisier and set up his own d-ualistic system, claiming that he had found substances which were simpler than the chemical elements - andronia and thelycke - which he identified with the acidic and basic principles. He claimed that all matter was composed of these, and with their aid he attempted to explain all chemical phenomena. His ideas miet with a mixed reception. He claimed several times to have isolated the acidic and basic principles, but his experiments could not be duplicated. The Danish physicist Oersted first clhampioned Winterl's ideas, then rejected them. Winterl's system was enthusiastically received by the adherents of Natuirphilosophie. The acceptance of his dualistic concepts is a good example of the scienfiflc attitude of the German Romantic era - a search for unity and polarity in all of nature, often combined with speculation and a disdain for experiment. An unfortunate experiment: Hertz and the nature of cathode rays. Notes Rec. R. Soc. Lond., 1970,25:237-242. 2443 TORNEBOHM, HAKAN. Two studies concerning the Michelson-Morley experiment. Found. Physics, 1970, 1:47-56. "In the first of these two studies it is argued that the dis- crepancy between the predicted and actual outcome of the Michelson-Morley experiment is due to the use of Newton's velocity addition theorem in conjunction with an electro- magnetic theory of light. The ether hypothesis is not directly affected at all. The second study is a case study of the re- moval of a clash in physics generated from the outcome of an experiment. The clash due to the Michelson-Morley experiment gave rise to a program of revision. In the process of implementation of this program Newtonian mechanics was reusiolded. It is argued that the Riemannian space-time in Einstein's general theory of relativity may be regarded as a successor of the classical ether." From the summary. 2444 TOMA?, MILAN. Breif discussion of the discoveries of five substances from natural sources by Japanese workers who published in local publications and were obscured by later investigators. Moscow: Nauka, 1967. 2484 O'BRIEN, CHARLES F. Eozoon Canadense, "the dawn animal of Canada". Isis, 1970, 61:206-223. "Eozoon Canadense, 'the dawn animal of Canada', was found in the Precambrian rocks of eastern Canada in 1858. The discovery startled the geological world, since at the time few paleontologists believed that such metamorphic rocks could preserve fossils or even that life could have existed so long ago. In fact, what we now call Precambrian was then com- monly designated by the term Azoic - lifeless. It is not sur- prising, then, that the authenticity of Lozoon Canadense was disputed. TIse ensuing controversy lasted for nearly fifty years and developed into one of the most contentious issues in 19th-centurv geology." 2485 O'BRIEN, CHARLES F. Hippocr., 1967,38:31-32. 2510 CHURCHILL, FREDERICK B. Hertwig, Weismann, and the meaning of reduction division circa 1890. Isis, 1970, 61:429457. "As the body of this paper will emphasize, howrever, it is not enough to show that the physiologists pledged allegiance to a chemical and dynamic hereditary process and that the morphologists proclaimed the existence of a particulate and static material; nor is it enough to bring to light their reveised concerns over the two-sided coin of development and inheritance. The historian must examine the theoretical manipu- lations of the hereditary material as each investigator fashioned his explanatory model out of certain assumptiotis and the rapidly expanding body of facts. There is no better way of showing how deeds speak louder than words than by comparing the professedly morphological and explicitly particulate tlieories of Oscar Hertwig (1849-1922) and August Weismauin (1834-1914) as each explained the theoretical irviplicttionis of reduction division in one of the liveliest controversies in cytology during the 1890s. The explicatic,n of this controversy sheds light on material theories in general and suggests why there was a resurgence - better yet, a re- action - of nonmaterial theories after 1900." 2511 CHESNOKOVA, S. A.; M. LINDEMANN. Wissenschaftliche Kontakte zwischen Physiologen aus Russland und aus Deutschland in der zweiten Hglfte des vorigen Jahrhunderts. NTM, 1970, 7(1):85-98. 2512 CLAPAREDE, EDOUARD. (Basler Ver6ffentlichungen zur Geschichte der Medizin und der Biolo e, 29.) 75 pp., bibl. Basel: Schwabe, 1971. Sfr 15. 2513 COLEMAN, WILLIAM. Bateson and chromosomets: Conservative thought in science. Centaurus, 1970, 15:228-314. "In 1910 Bateson's views commanded allegiance and careful attention;by 1915 they were already subject to considenable and often severe attack; by 1926. the year of his death, both he and his contemporaries realized that, apart from their empirical bases, most of his Mendelian generalizations had been surpassed or refuted. To record this sequence of events will be one of the objectives of this essay. I shall discuss snore inclusively Bateson's training and intentions as a student of genetic phenomena. The alternatives which he opposed to the ascendant chromosome theory will receive full examina- tion; they portray perhaps best of all the substance of his criticism of all materialistic theories of inheritance ... I shall argue that emphasis upon experiential concreteness-ao. intuitionist epistemology and associated acute aesthetic sensibility and the terms of the metaphor of the social organism each and all bind Bateson lirmly to the renaissait conservative movement of the late 19th century." 2514 COLEMAN, WILLIAM. "There is never ... a historiographical substitute for two tasks: analysing an author's arguments strictly in his own terms, and relating those arguments, as far as possible, to the problems dominating the pertinent theoretical discus- sions of the day. My purpose here is to pursue the first as a prolegomenon to any future efforts at the second of these tasks. My strategy will be to start by exploring in considerable detail the main claims of Lamarck's 'biology'. Then, in the second part of the paper, I want to exhibit the influence of the early Lamarck on the late Lamarck. Finally, my general conclusion will be that Lamarck's 'biology' was a natural philosophy project thoroughly characteristic of the late Enlightenment." 2546 HOLT, NILES R. Emst Haeckel's monistic religion. J. Hist. Ideas, 1971,32:265-280. "The purpose of this paper is to trace the history of the Monistic Reiigion from its inception as an obscure part of the young Haeckel's materialistic-mechanistic view of Darwinism to its distinct emergence, near the end of his life, as an idealistic and semivitalistic version of the Darwinian theory of evolution." 2547 HOLTHUIS, L. "The concept that foods must contain organic trace nutrients in addition to adequate amounts of fats, carbohydrates, proteins, and minerals was clearly enunciated in 1912 and became firmly established as part of a continuing traditior during the next decade. MThe body of the paper consists of an account of the crucial role which the analogy between 'artifical' and 'natural' selection played in the development, exposition, and reception of Darwin's theory. I shall then argue that this analogy provides an opportunity to show the theological, philo- sophical, and scientific difficulties which he encountered in his own writings and in his correspondence. I hope tnat this account will provide some new materials for historians of philosophy and intellectual historians to consider in their examination of three related issues in the 19th-century debate: (1) man's place in nature; (2' the relationships between man, God, and nature; (3) the philosophies of science and of nature." 2626 YOUNG, ROBERT M. SocioL. 1968, 9:37-71. 2653 CLARK, TERRY N. The structure and functions of a research institute: The Annee sociologique. Archs Europ. Sociol, 1968,9:72-91. The Annie sociologique is generally refered to simply as a scholarly journal. But while it was neither so large nor so structured as many more recent creations, it is the thesis of this paper that for many purposes the Annee may be usefully conceived of as a research institute. Organizing the Annee sociologique led to much more than simply the cataloguing of annual developments in sociology; through it Durkheim was able to achieve many other goals which in a more recent period he might have achieved through a research institute. Given the constraints of academic life of the period, how- ever, the Annee sociologique served as a remarkably successful functional altemative. 2654 COLE, NORWOOD M. Coll., 1971,107:173-193. "The racial thinking of Nathaniel Southgate Shaler (1841- 1906), Dean of the Laurence Scientific School at Harvard, epitomized in many ways the most 'scientifically' accepted attitudes of the late 19th century on the Negro, the immi- grant, and the so-called 'inferior races'. Studies the period between 1880-1914 in the United Kingdom. A fragment of Freud's library. PsychoanaL Q., 1971, 40:491495. 2697 HARRISON, BRIAN. Drink and sobriety in England, 1815-1872: A critical bibliography. Int. Rev. Soc. Hist., 1967, 12:204-276. 2698 HENLE, MARY. Did Titchener commit the stimulus error?: The problem of meaning in structural psycho- logy. J. Hist. Behavl Sci, 1971, 7:279-282 2699 HILTS, VICTOR L. William Farr (1807-1883) and the "human unit". Victorian Stud., 1970, 14:143-150. "One of the most important changes in social attitudes which occurred during the middle of the 19th century was the transition between a social concem which emphasized 'moral' factors- such as education- and one which emphasized 'biological' factors- such as the 'quality' of the population. The cause of this change has often been correlated with the development of social Darwinism, with the rise of the sciences of anthropology, or with European colonial expansion. When one examines the change in more detail in England, however, it becomes clear that the shift was already well underway before the publication of the Origin of species in 1859 and was not simply the result of colonial expansion. One 19th-century Englishman who exemplifies the shift from an explanation of social problems in terms of moral factors to an explanation of social in terms of biological factors is sanitarian William Farr. His career also illustrates the extreme importance of the English sanitary movement as a basic cause of the change." 2700 HIMMELFARB, GERTRUDE. Mayhew's poor: A problem of identity. Victorian Stud., 1971, 14:307-320. Discusses Henry Mayhew's London labour and the London eoor in an attempt to determine who actually were "the poor" m Victorian England. 2701 HINDELAND, MICHAEL J. Towards a reassessment of Comte's Methode positive. Philosophy Sci, 1971, 38:35-53. Abstract:`In this study of Comte's philosophy of science, an attempt is made to explicate his views on such methodological issues as explanation, prediction, induction and hypothesis. Comte's efforts to resolve the dual problems of demarcation and meaning led to the enunciation of principles of verifia- bility and predictabiity. Comte's hypothetico-deductive method is seen to permit conjectures dealing with unobservable entities." 2712 LEE, S. G. M.; MARTIN HERBERT (eds.) Stuttgart: Freies Geistesleben, 1970. DM 12. 2811 HOWARD-JONES, NORMAN. The origins of hypodermic medication. Scient. APL, 1971, 224(1):96-102. The Scottish physician, Alexander Wood, introduced the procedure of hypodermic injection in 1853 "as a means of anesthetizing peripheral nerves and thereby relieving pain in patients with neuralgia. Another peculiarity in the history of this method of administering drugs was that for many years it was not recognized that the hypodermic injection of morphine, which was regarded as a harmless substitute for taking the drug orally in the form of opium, was the equal of or the superior to opium-eating in producing drug addiction. A third curiosity in thss strange story is that nearly all the standard histories of medicine attribute the introduction of hypodermic medication to the wrong man, the French physician Charles Gabriel Pravaz." 2812 HUARD, PIERRE A. Stevens (1853-1943) surveyed and built the line of the Great Northem Railway through the Rocky and Cascade mountains to Puget Sound, Outstanding features were switchbacks, loops, and the famous Cascade tunnel. The latter, opened in 1900, "was hailed as the engineering marvel of its day". After building other lines, he became chief engineer in charge of planning and constuction of the Panama Canal. In the 1920's he headed the American Railway Mission to Russia. He received many awards in the United States and from foreign govemments. M. GORMAN 2892 CUNY, HILAIRE. "Into hostile political camps": The reorgnization of intemational science in World War 1. Isis, 1971, 62:47-60. "In 1946 Hugo R. Kruyt, the president of the International Council of Scientific Unions, warned the deleptes at the opening of the oranization's first postwar meeting that they would do well to keep politics as far from science as possible'. For as Kruyt reminded his colleagues, the develop- ment of international cooperation in research had been paralzed for over a decade after Versailles, largely because sn World War I his predecessors had reconstructed the major scientific organizatons of the world on a political basis. Apart from the importance of its aftereffects, the reorganization during the Great War deserves historical attention in its own right. And now that the papers of the chief figure in the story, George Ellery Hale, have become available to scholars, the episode can be told in revealing detail." 2976 KRAUTH, LOTHAR. British scientists and "outsider" politics, 1931-1945. Sci Stud (London), 1971, 1:67-83. "In this paper ... emphasis will be placed on important ideo- logical divisions between the leaders of the Science and Society Movement. The fact that a scientists' 'popular front' was achieved will be explained in terms both of the low status accorded their profession by the nation's political and intellectual elites up until 1939, and of the subsequent demand for scientific expertise during the Second World War. As political 'outsiders', it was therefore natural that at least some British scientists attempted to influence public policy through the formation of pressure groups independent of both the Govemment and party politics. After discussing the development and decline of the alliance of socially conscious researchers, the paper will conclude with a brief comparison between the scientists' movements of the Thirties and those of the present day." 2986 WITTGENSTEIN, LUDWIG. Sci Applic., 1971,24:99-105. 3005 BROGLIE, LOUIS DE. Notice sur la vie et l'oeuvre de Bernard Lyot. Lecture faite en la seance annuelle des prix du 8 decembre 1969. 16 pp., port. Paris Palais de l'Institut, 1969. 3006 BROGLIE, LOUIS DE. The reinterpretation of wave mechanics. Found. Physics, 1970, 1:5-15. "The author begins by recalling how he was led in 1923-24 to the ideas of wave mechanics in generalizing the ideas of Einstein's theory of light quanta. He made himself at that time a concrete physical picture of the coexistence of waves and particles and, in 1927, attempted to give them precise form in this 'theory of the double solution'. As other ideas pre- vailed at the time, he abandoned the development of his conception. But for the past twenty years, once again con- vinced, like Einstein, that present-day quantum mechanics is only a statistical theory and does not give a true picture of physical reality, he has again taken up his old ideas and developed them considerably. He has in particular introduced an element of randomness into the theory and has thus attained to a 'hidden thermodynamics of particles', the results of which appear to be very interesting." From the summary. 3007 BROMBERG, JOAN L. Heisenberg's papers on nuclear structure. Actes XIIe Cong. Int. Hist. Sci, 1968 (pub. 1971), 5:13-15. 3008 CAMPBELL, WILLIAM A.; NORMAN N. GREENWOOD. Crucial experiments in modem physics. ix + 141 pp. New York: Van Nostrand Reinhold Company, 1971. $2.95 (paper). This is one of the Momentum Books published for the Com- mission on College Physics, desiped for use in college physics courses. Since special relativity and the discovery of the electron have been covered in previous books by Robert Kate and David L. Anderson in the same series, these topics are omitted from the present volume. There are chapters on the origin of the quantum concept, transmutation of elements. existence of atoms (Brownian movement), the atomic nucleus collisions of electrons with atoms, photoelectric affect, spatiaf orientation of atomic magnets, particle properties of light, and wave properties of matter. Each chapter is a mixture of histor- ical/technical exposition by the author, and extensive extracts from original sources. The book would also be suitable as a text for a course in the history of modem physics for students with some physics background. S. G. BRUSH 3087 U. S. ATOMIC ENERGY COMMISSION. In the matter of J. Organismic and holistic concepts of thought of L. J. Henderson. J. Hist. BioL, 1971, 4:63-113. "Te career of L. J. Henderson involved a progression from she study of simple and artificial systems, such as aqueous solutions of phosphates, to the investipation of complex and natural systems, such as blood and socsety. Dunrng the course of this progression, his philosophical views underwent considerable change, although ideas such as system, equi- librium, organization, and fitness retain their place in his thisking throughout his mature life. This paper will deal with the origin and development of these concepts in Henderson's thought, especially in relation to his biologscal researches." 3114 SANDERS, A. P. M.; H. DE VRIES. Mendel Newsletter, 1971, 7:7-11. Essay review of D. Joravsky, The Lysenko affair (Cambridge, Mas., 1970). 3118 STAFLEU, FRANS A. Fifty years of intemational biology. Taxon, 1971, 20:14 1-151. "A review of the development of the International Union of Biological Sciences (IUBS) since its establishment in 1919, preceded by some remarks on the origin of 'biology' as a discipline and on 19th-century international cooperation in the natural sciences. After a rather slow start in the years before the second World War, in which the activities were mainly centered upon the section of botany, IUBS developed fully, after 1945, into a truly representative international forum for biology. The most pressing problems facing biology and IUBS in the early seventies-documentation and the environment- are briefly discussed with special reference to the change of attitude apparent in biology, as well as in biologists, from 'pure' and 'detached' to a social and cultural 'engagement'." From the summary. 3119 TEICH, M1KLAS. The history of modern bio- chemistry, the second phase: c. 1920-1940/45. Actes XIIe Cong. Int. Hist. Sc, 1968 (pub. 1971), 8:199-203. 3120 VYVYAN, JOHN. Eklund, Isis, 1969, 60:242.</page><page sequence="201">207 INDEX TO THE NINETY-SEVENTH CRITICAL BIBLIOGRAPHY The following index contains all the personal names appearing in the Critical Bibliography. It also contains the names of institutions when used as author or sub- ject. To enhance the usefulness of the index all cita- tions for a given person have been consolidated under the best-known form of his name, with preference shown for the anglicized version. A cross-reference can usually be found under the common variations (e.g. "Ibn STna, see Avicenna"). We have, hopefully, observed the established usage in alphabetizing foreign names (e.g. De Morgan, Augustus; L6pez Pifiero, Jose' Maria; Watanabe, Masao; Li Yen; al-Brrunr-under B; Ibn Qurra-under I). In the 97th Critical Bibliography each citation has been given an individual number. The numbers in this index, therefore, refer to specific citations, not to pages. Numbers in roman style refer to items in which the person or institution indexed is either the author, editor, or translator of the citation. Italic numbers refer to items in which the person or institution indexed is treated as a subject.
